title: Urine Output and Fluid Balance
description: Calculates 24-hour urine output rate and fluid balance for assessment of renal function and fluid status. Helps identify oliguria, polyuria, and fluid imbalances in hospitalized patients.

parameters.name: urine_output_ml
parameters.description: Total urine output in milliliters over the collection period

parameters.name: collection_hours
parameters.description: Number of hours for urine collection period

parameters.name: fluid_intake_ml
parameters.description: Total fluid intake in milliliters during the same collection period

result.name: urine_output_rate
result.description: Calculated urine output rate per kg body weight per hour

ranges.interpretation: Critically low urine output (<0.3 mL/kg/hr) indicating severe acute renal failure or anuria. This level sustained for >24 hours or complete anuria for >12 hours suggests acute kidney injury requiring immediate nephrology consultation and intervention.

Low urine output (0.3-0.5 mL/kg/hr) indicating oliguria. This level sustained for >12 hours may indicate acute kidney injury. Monitor closely and evaluate for underlying causes such as volume depletion, nephrotoxic medications, or intrinsic renal disease.

Lower normal urine output (0.5-1.0 mL/kg/hr). This is within acceptable range but monitor for trends. Ensure adequate hydration and evaluate if sustained at lower end of range with clinical signs of volume depletion.
Normal urine output (1.0-2.0 mL/kg/hr) indicating adequate renal function and fluid balance. This range suggests normal kidney function and appropriate fluid status in most clinical contexts.

High urine output (>2.0 mL/kg/hr) indicating polyuria. Evaluate for diabetes insipidus, diabetes mellitus, diuretic use, excessive fluid intake, or resolving acute tubular necrosis. May require further investigation and management.

references: Kellum JA, Lameire N, Aspelin P, et al. Kidney disease: improving global outcomes (KDIGO) acute kidney injury work group. KDIGO clinical practice guideline for acute kidney injury. Kidney Int Suppl. 2012;2(1):1-138.
Macedo E, Malhotra R, Bouchard J, Wynn SK, Mehta RL. Oliguria is an early predictor of higher mortality in critically ill patients. Kidney Int. 2011;80(7):760-767.
formula: Urine Output Rate (mL/kg/hr) = Total Urine Output (mL) / (Weight (kg) Ã— Collection Hours)
notes: Normal 24-hour urine output in adults is 800-2000 mL (approximately 1 mL/kg/hr)
Oliguria is defined as <400 mL urine output in 24 hours or <0.5 mL/kg/hr for >6 hours
Anuria is defined as <50 mL urine output in 24 hours or absent urine output for >12 hours
Polyuria is defined as >3000 mL urine output in 24 hours or >50 mL/kg in 24 hours
Fluid balance calculation: Intake - Output = Net fluid balance (positive = retention, negative = loss)
Consider insensible losses (approximately 400-800 mL/day in adults) when assessing total fluid balance
Urine output monitoring is essential in critically ill patients and those with AKI risk factors
Factors affecting urine output: age, medications, comorbidities, fluid status, and renal function
Use in conjunction with serum creatinine, BUN, and clinical assessment for complete evaluation
Important for monitoring response to diuretics, fluid resuscitation, and nephrotoxic medications
